  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The Nation
















Hi everyone,
 
On the anniversary of
  the Columbine school massacre, it is a day of complex mourning. Vigils and
  moments of silence across the country remembered the lives of the 32 victims
  of Monday’s tragedy at Virginia Tech – but the observances were
  haunted by ghosts of what the similar tragedy eight years ago at Columbine
  high School in Littleton,
   Colorado. Sharyn Alfonsi will
  have the story of this day of mourning. 
 
Our chief investigative
  correspondent Armen Keteyian will continue coverage of how Seung-Hui Cho obtained
  his weapons.
 
One day after embattled
  Attorney General Alberto Gonzales attempted to explain the firings of eight
  federal prosecutors to a Senate panel, the White House stepped up to back
  him. Has he done a “fantastic job,” as a spokesperson said today,
  or is he about to lose his job? Jim Axelrod will have the latest.
 
And Nancy Cordes will report on the investigation
  into the pet food contamination scare. The FDA suggests that much of the
  recalled pet food may have been intentionally spiked with an industrial
  chemical that would boost their protein content. We’ll take a closer
  look.
 
Meanwhile, the stock
  market is racing toward a new milestone – thanks to strong earnings
  reports from Internet superstar Google Inc. Anthony Mason will have more.
 
Finally, Steve Hartman will
  have a story about a warmhearted man who’s helping get homeless people
  off the street. He’s drastically improved the lives of many people.
  How? With massive quantities of hot dogs – really. Join us for his
  story.
 
I hope you have a
  wonderful weekend.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
